complexityChecks.description: When supported by the stack, run cyclomatic complexity or similar metrics in CI as a warning-only check initially.

qualityGatePolicy.description: New quality checks should warn on existing code and fail CI only for violations introduced in new or changed code, to reduce friction on legacy codebases.

migrationGuide.title: Establish Local Safety Nets First
migrationGuide.description: Start by adding pre-commit hooks and core formatting/linting so developers get fast feedback without touching CI.
migrationGuide.notes: Keep hooks fast and focused on changed files to avoid slowing down day-to-day work.

migrationGuide.title: Mirror Local Checks in CI (Soft-Fail on Legacy)
migrationGuide.description: Introduce CI quality gates that mirror local checks, but treat existing violations as warnings wherever possible.
migrationGuide.notes: Use diff-based tools or baselines so only new violations break builds; legacy issues remain visible but non-blocking.

migrationGuide.title: Add Type Safety, Coverage, and Dependency Security
migrationGuide.description: Enable type-checking, coverage thresholds, and dependency/vulnerability scanning with gradual enforcement.
migrationGuide.notes: Pin tool and runtime versions in CI and containers to avoid flaky differences across environments.

migrationGuide.title: Layer in Docs, Governance, and Recommended Checks
migrationGuide.description: Add documentation standards, governance files, integration testing, performance baselines, complexity analysis, accessibility auditing, and (optionally) ML-specific practices for data-heavy Python repos.
migrationGuide.notes: Tackle recommended items in order of business value; backend-only repos can skip web-focused checks like accessibility. For AI/ML-heavy Python teams, consider extending containerization with data versioning (DVC) and unit tests with data quality checks (e.g., Great Expectations) as part of this step.

core.label: Git and Docker Ignore Files
core.description: Maintain proper .gitignore and .dockerignore files to prevent committing secrets, build artifacts, or unnecessary files.

stack.notes: Use the official github/gitignore Python template. Include **pycache**, .venv/, .pytest_cache, .env, and similar local-only files. .dockerignore must exclude .git, virtual environments, and caches.
stack.verification: .gitignore must exist; .dockerignore is recommended when containerizing or using Docker workflows.

core.label: Linting
core.description: Run static code linting to enforce consistency and catch common issues early.

stack.notes: Configure a primary linter (such as ruff) and keep rules focused on catching real issues without overwhelming developers.
stack.verification: pyproject.toml (or ruff.toml / .flake8 / setup.cfg) signals that linting tools are configured for the repository.

bazelHints.notes: Example only; actual targets are repo-defined. Use rules_python with ruff wrapped as py_test or run target.

core.label: Unit Test Runner
core.description: Provide a deterministic unit test framework with a single command to run all tests.

stack.notes: Organize unit tests under a tests/ directory and avoid real network or database calls in this layer.
stack.verification: Test framework configuration is present; tests/ directory or pytest configuration exists.

bazelHints.notes: Example only; actual targets are repo-defined. Use rules_python py_test for pytest-based tests.

core.label: Containerization (Docker / Docker Compose)
core.description: Provide a Dockerfile and, if applicable, a docker-compose file for local dev and CI parity.

stack.notes: Choose a slim Python base image, pin the version, and clearly document how to start the service in a container.
stack.verification: Dockerfile must be present; docker-compose.yml is optional and indicates orchestration usage.

core.label: Semantic Versioning
core.description: Use MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH versioning with clear rules and automated changelog generation based on commit history.

stack.notes: Automate version bumping and changelog generation using setuptools_scm (git-tag based) or bumpversion with towncrier for changelog fragments. Configure CI to automatically update version in pyproject.toml, generate/update CHANGELOG.md from commit messages or changelog fragments, and create git tags. Maintain a single source of truth for versioning.
stack.verification: Check that the package version in pyproject or setup configuration follows SemVer and verify that the configured tool (for example, setuptools_scm or bumpversion) automatically computes or bumps the version and generates changelog entries from commit history or fragments.

core.label: Commit Linting
core.description: Enforce structured commit messages such as Conventional Commits.

stack.notes: Standardize commit messages using commitizen or a similar helper and document the required types and scopes.
stack.verification: Use the configured commit helper (for example, commitizen) or hooks to create a test commit and confirm that non-conforming messages are rejected while valid ones are accepted.

core.label: Unit Test Reporter / Coverage
core.description: Generate readable unit test and coverage reports and enforce a minimum coverage threshold (around 80%) for new or changed code.

stack.notes: Configure coverage reporting for your test suite and surface summary metrics in CI.
stack.verification: Run the unit tests with coverage (for example, pytest with pytest-cov) and confirm that coverage reports are generated and referenced in CI to enforce or track thresholds.

bazelHints.notes: Use rules_python py_test with coverage instrumentation. Combine with --combined_report=lcov.

core.label: CI Quality Gates
core.description: Single CI pipeline that runs linting, formatting, type checking, tests, coverage, build, and containerization.

stack.notes: Ensure CI runs linting, type checking (if used), tests, and packaging or container checks for Python services before merging.
stack.verification: Open the CI configuration and verify there is a job or stage that runs linting, type checking (if used), tests, and any packaging or container checks before merging to main.

bazelHints.notes: Bazel py_binary and py_test targets replace traditional Python tooling.

core.label: Code Formatter
core.description: Automatic code formatting to maintain a consistent style across all contributors.

stack.notes: Use black (or an equivalent opinionated formatter) and treat its output as the single source of truth for code style.
stack.verification: Run the configured formatter (for example, `black .` or `black --check .`) and confirm it reports clean formatting on committed code and auto-fixes as expected locally.

bazelHints.notes: Wrap black as a py_binary run target for format checking.

core.label: Pre-Commit Hooks
core.description: Use git hooks to run linting, formatting, tests, and commit linting before changes are committed.

stack.notes: Use pre-commit to run ruff, black, and optionally mypy on staged files before committing.
stack.verification: Inspect .pre-commit-config.yaml and confirm that hooks for linting, formatting, and optionally type checking are enabled and run on changed files before commits.

core.label: Type Checking
core.description: Use static type checking to catch errors before runtime and enforce strictness on new code.

stack.notes: Adopt gradual typing with type hints and mypy, focusing first on critical modules and new code paths.
stack.verification: pyproject.toml (or mypy.ini) signals that mypy configuration is available for the repository.

bazelHints.notes: Example only; actual targets are repo-defined. Wrap mypy as a py_test or run target.

core.label: Dependency Management & Vulnerability Scanning
core.description: Lock dependencies and scan regularly for known vulnerabilities; fail CI on newly introduced high-severity issues.

stack.notes: Pin dependency versions and routinely scan for vulnerabilities, prioritizing fixes for critical and high-severity issues.
stack.verification: Dependency lockfile is present; security scanning is configured in CI or project tooling.

core.label: Runtime Version Specification
core.description: Specify required runtime/engine versions in package manifests to ensure environment stability and prevent version-related issues across development teams.

stack.notes: Specify python_requires in pyproject.toml (e.g., requires-python = ">=3.9") or setup.py (e.g., python_requires='>=3.9'). Consider adding .python-version for pyenv users to automatically switch to the correct Python version.
stack.verification: pyproject.toml or setup.py must specify python_requires; .python-version is recommended for local development.

core.label: Documentation Standards
core.description: Maintain a comprehensive README and, where applicable, auto-generated API docs to support onboarding and maintainability.

stack.notes: Ensure README explains environment setup and core commands, and generate API docs from docstrings where appropriate.
stack.verification: README.md is present in the repository root; docs/ directory or documentation tooling configuration exists if applicable.

core.label: Repository Governance
core.description: Include standard governance files (LICENSE, CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md, CONTRIBUTING.md), branch protection rules, and review standards to define legal, ethical, and workflow expectations.

stack.notes: Spell out contributor responsibilities for tests, documentation, and review so expectations are clear for Python-focused teams.
stack.verification: LICENSE file is present in the repository root; CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md and CONTRIBUTING.md are present for contribution guidance.

recommended.description: Automate dependency updates using Renovate or Dependabot to keep dependencies current and reduce security exposure window.

recommended.label: Dependency Architecture Rules
recommended.description: Enforce module boundaries and import constraints to prevent architectural drift and unwanted coupling.

azure-devops.notes: CI hints are suggested mappings; adjust to your pipeline topology.

recommended.label: Integration Testing
recommended.description: Test how components interact with each other and external systems, running after unit tests with more relaxed coverage thresholds.

stack.notes: Separate integration tests from unit tests, using fixtures to handle databases, services, or other external systems.
stack.verification: Confirm there is a separate integration or API test suite (for example, a dedicated tests/integration directory) and run it to verify interactions with databases, services, or external systems.

recommended.label: Performance Baselines
recommended.description: Establish performance baselines and monitor for regressions using lightweight benchmarks or audits in CI.

stack.notes: Use simple benchmarks or profiling runs to characterize bottlenecks and watch for regressions in critical workflows.
stack.verification: Identify and run the configured performance checks or benchmarks (for example, pytest-benchmark or cProfile-based scripts) and confirm that their results are recorded and compared over time.

recommended.label: Complexity Analysis
recommended.description: Measure cyclomatic complexity or similar metrics to keep code maintainable, starting as a warning-only check.

stack.notes: Use radon or similar tools to track complexity of Python functions and keep new code within acceptable limits.
stack.verification: Run the configured complexity tool (for example, radon) on the codebase and review the report to ensure new or heavily changed functions are not excessively complex.

recommended.label: Accessibility Auditing
recommended.description: Run accessibility checks on web-facing components to detect critical issues and improve inclusive UX.

stack.notes: Use headless browser-based tools to scan Python-backed web UIs for accessibility issues on high-traffic routes.
stack.verification: For Python-backed web UIs, run the configured accessibility tooling (for example, pa11y or axe via a headless browser) against key routes and verify that critical issues are fixed or tracked.

optionalEnhancements.label: Observability (Logging & Error Handling)
optionalEnhancements.description: Standardize error handling and structured logging to make debugging and production monitoring easier.

stack.notes: Use structured logging for Python services and ensure critical paths record enough context to debug issues after the fact.
stack.verification: Confirm that a structured logging setup (such as structlog or configured logging with JSON formatting) is in place and that critical paths log enough information to debug failures in production.
